Concrete can dry out if not cured properly and protected from excessive heat/wind. The water within a fresh mix causes the hardening of concrete through a process called hydration. If the freshly placed concrete is not properly protected, the water within the concrete could escape and potentially lead to shrinkage cracking due to change in volume and overall weakness.

That is not completely true. Concrete actually does dry out. The shrinkage of concrete is mainly because water evaporates.There are two types of shrinkage: the drying shrinkage, which is because water evaporates and the autogenous shrinkage, which is due to hydration of the cement. The drying shrinkage is approximately 3-4 times larger than the autogenous shrinkage. Therefore, concrete dries out more than it sets.

I keep reading about concrete and I have discovered something a little bit disturbing. Apparently it keeps absorbing CO2 from the air and this changes the acidity of it. If the concrete is not reinforced this is not a problem but if it is reinforced it means the concrete will eat away at the reinforcement metal bars. This happens in about 100 years. So here's my question: does this mean that all the reinforced concrete structures we've built in the 20th century are doomed? Will they all start failing towards the end of the 21st century? None of the materials that talk about the carbonification of concrete dare to approach this issue. What do you think?

the problem with the bit at the end is that roman concrete was actuall fundamentally different from what we use today.  a 10 year old bit of roman concrete would still be much stronger than a ten year old bit of modern concrete, since it has a different recipe.  why don't we use the roman recipie?  two reasons: 1) The Roman recipie had been lost to history until very recently when we found a document describing it, which it turns out 2) calls for volcanic ash.

For greatest strenght, pour the concrete as dry as possible. Once it sets, keep it wet for as long as you can. Some use burlap sacks to keep it wet.

Also, concrete has high compression strength, very low tensile (stretching) strength.

The strength of concrete is the gravel. Sand fits between the gravel. Cement fits between the sand. Water fits between the cement (powder). More water than that weakens the final product, but is needed for ease of laying it.

Concrete does in fact dry out. Concrete erodes with water; too much water overtime=too much evaporation of that water overtime (due to hot weather). If your science is in fact true, then you would also take into account the fact that concrete expands and contracts on the daily, due to the drastic changes of temperature overtime. Therefore, when it rains the once hot concrete is now cooler (since water is a natural coolant). Then the hot dry concrete will absorb the water, and once it gets hot enough for evaporation of that water to take place, the concrete will essentially dry out. The chemical bonding of concrete with water only takes place once the concrete is initially mixed and poured to set. So yes people, concrete does dry out. Sooner than one would even think, or perhaps even believe.

ALTERNATE CIVIL WAR ENDING: The South wins the Civil War with British and French help, but in WWI, we (and our German and Austrian allies) manage to eliminate the Confederates,
who flee to Europe and Mexico. Shortly thereafter, Canada and Ireland are invaded as unrestricted submarine warfare guts the economy of the U.K. France surrenders to Germany/Austria,
Canada is carved into American states (1928, 29-32), and Ireland becomes an American Protectorate. America vows to return to isolationism after the war; Britain vows its Empire will survive. The badly beaten French vow revenge for this loss; in 1929, a French Nationalist (and WWI survivor) named DeGaulle rises to power in a far right party, vowing to rearm, resist, and push the Kaiser into the Baltic. Several far right parties coalesce around DeGaulle, and his speeches become things of spectacle.
When civil war breaks out in Spain, he sends more than fifty thousand French Soldiers
to eliminate the 'dangerous' socialist Republic. France declares itself "Nationaliste" Spain, by 1930, is an ally, under General
Francisco Franco. Italy joins into this alliance in 1932. The U.K. flirts with joining, but does not.
Meanwhile, the Germans are being bled dry by the 'Great Northern War' which pitted the German Empire and Finland against the Soviet Union in a defensive war against the Soviets expanding into the Baltic states and Finland. With their economies weakened, the Austrians collapse (in 1934) leading to several years of disarray before another government can be seated.The Monarchy is gone, however. In 1935, mass protests and riots cripple Germany itself, and Frederick III is assassinated in Leipzig, ostensibly by French provacateurs.
America, meanwhile, fights a dirty war against Mexican Guerrillas, armed and trained by
the fleeing Confederates and Anglo-French mercenaries. Whole villages are quietly eliminated, and thousands of soldiers die in the relentless, tireless war of attrition. As President Teddy Roosevelt laments 'There are no good wars; only good men doing terrible things." (L.A. Times, 1932)
In the Far East, Japan expands into China, Taiwan, Mongolia, and, on April 14th, 1934,
crosses the Amur River, into Siberia, with a sudden, unprovoked attack on Port Arthur that destroys the Soviet Eastern Fleet completely. This is done to get at Soviet fuel supplies, needed by the Japanese in order to expand further in China. By the end of May,
1934, more than a million Imperial Japanese Soldiers are in Siberia, and Stalin is forced to attempt making a temporary peace with the Germans to move his beleaguered forces east.
July 3rd, 1934. Stalin is killed in the Kremlin as the Germans firebomb Moscow with long range Focke-Wulf 202 Condor Bombers.
* WW2***

My brother, who works in concrete, demonstrated by sticking a thermometer into a ball of "wet" cement. The temperature RISES as the chemical reaction occurs; evaporation would LOWER the temperature, like sweating cools your skin. That is why you see fresh cement covered in burlap; to hold heat and prolong the reaction.

Actually, concrete is not a mixture of the things you cited. Portland cement, the binder of concrete, is made by burning calcium carbonate, which "calcines" it into calcium oxide, then mixing it with silicon dioxide or sand, and iron oxide or rust. Then it is fused inside a very hot furnace to form "clinker" which contains the cement made of calcium di- and tri-silicates, which form the spicules you mentioned when these hydrates are given an abundance of water to bind into their molecule. Then the clinker is ground in a huge grinder and screen separated into grades of Portland cement powder, which is what you mix with sand and gravel or rock to form concrete when it sets. The water is retained, in fact you can pour concrete under water and it sets even faster. If you pour a concrete slab you want to water it several times daily if you want it to become very hard.

Also interesting is when concrete cures it heats up.  Engineers calculated that if the Hoover Dam had been built as one continuous pour it'd take 125 years to cool to ambient temperatures (so around 2056).  However, this would have caused serious structural problems for the dam so they didn't do that and had to find another means to build the dam.

When working with a low slump concrete, with LOW water content initially, it is critical to wet it after it first sets. I pond projects that require peak strength, allowing continuous water contact. Like you said, it is a hydration reaction.
When working with fiber reinforced concrete, any excess water would cause severe drops in strength. The mix is 60oz water with 80lbs of concrete... An incredibly dry mixture, yet it is still workable with a little patience. While setting, I mist it to keep the surface moist but not soaked. Once initially set (about 2 hours), I prepare the pond or enclosure and literally leave it in a bath. Cracking due to drying in the first few hours or days reduces the strength permanently.
